passages.text: The derivative of a function f(x) at a point x is defined as the limit of the difference quotient as h approaches zero: f'(x) = lim(h→0) [f(x+h) - f(x)]/h
The chain rule states that if y = f(g(x)), then dy/dx = f'(g(x)) · g'(x). This is used to find derivatives of composite functions.
The product rule states that if y = u(x) · v(x), then dy/dx = u'(x) · v(x) + u(x) · v'(x). This is used for differentiating products of functions.
